steps.title: Exercise to get in shape.
steps.content: Exercise to get in shape. Any physical activity, including cardio, will help to get you in shape for your first lesson. Aerial work targets the upper body and core, so focusing on those areas will help to get your ready and prevent injury. Try leg lifts, pull-ups, and horizontal rows. Invest in an at-home pull up/chin-up bar that you can practice on. It will improve your strength for climbing and holding yourself up in the future.

steps.title: Find a qualified teacher.
steps.content: Find a qualified teacher. No one should learn aerial silks on their own. It's extremely dangerous, and you could get seriously injured. The below steps should only be used to refresh your memory and practice in conjunction with a class. It is best to start with an aerial hammock class because that is the easiest way to learn. A hammock is a single piece of silky fabric and provides you with a safety net with the silk behind your back. [2] X Expert Source Bridgette Borzillo Dance Instructor & Artistic Director Expert Interview. 10 September 2021.

steps.title: Stretch[3] X Research source .
steps.content: Stretch [3] X Research source . Aerial silks use your muscles extensively. You want to have them stretched sufficiently before each class and practice session. [4] X Expert Source Bridgette Borzillo Dance Instructor & Artistic Director Expert Interview. 10 September 2021. Not only should you warm up your shoulders, arms and hamstrings, but it's also important to stretch out your hands. When stretching, also work on your straddle. You'll need this for future reference. [5] X Research source . Start your warm-up exercises with basic calisthenics, including jumping jacks, jogging in place, push-ups, and crunches Take your muscles through their typical range of motion with stretching exercises such as arm, shoulder, and neck circles, rolling your spine up and down, shaking out fingers and wrists, up-dog, down-dog, and the electric slide. You can even take an aerial yoga class. [6] X Expert Source Bridgette Borzillo Dance Instructor & Artistic Director Expert Interview. 10 September 2021.

steps.title: Climb the silks.
steps.content: Climb the silks. [7] X Research source Take the silk in both of your hands and wrap your strong-sided lower leg once around the silk.

steps.title: Pull up with your arms and place your free leg on top of your wrapped foot.
steps.content: Pull up with your arms and place your free leg on top of your wrapped foot. This is called a French Climb. Climbing is first and probably the most difficult trick for a beginner since the body is probably not used to such actions. But with the passage of time, it becomes easier to climb the silk. When you are pulling the silk, your arm should be sturdy and firm. Your grip on the silk should be stable so that you can concentrate on the movement of your lower limbs.

steps.title: Put your free foot on top of the silk.
steps.content: Put your free foot on top of the silk. That way it won't slip, and you're not supporting yourself with just your arms. This requires a lot of practice and stamina because it also involves your mental strength.

steps.title: Stand up and continue climbing until you've reached your desired height.
steps.content: Stand up and continue climbing until you've reached your desired height. You will want to remain near the ground until you've mastered the techniques.

steps.title: Learn the single foot lock.The basic move is easier to practice on the ground.
steps.content: Learn the single foot lock.The basic move is easier to practice on the ground. Wrap your lower leg around the silk as if you were going to climb. Pull some slack out of the silk from about mid-shin, and bring under your foot starting by your pinkie toe so it looks like you're wearing a shoe. Your toes and heel should not be in the silk.

steps.title: Climb down carefully.
steps.content: Climb down carefully. When coming down from a climb, walk yourself down slowly, hand over hand. If you slide down, you'll get painful second-degree burns on the top of your feet. Also, don't let go until you're at least only a foot off the ground.

steps.title: Tie yourself in either from the ground or from a climb.
steps.content: Tie yourself in either from the ground or from a climb. Separate the silks. Because the silk is hung from its middle, it hangs down with two separate pieces. When you're tied in, it looks like one. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Separate the two silks so you have two clearly visible pieces.
steps.content: Separate the two silks so you have two clearly visible pieces. Grip the separate silks so your elbows are level with the top of your head.

steps.title: Lean forward through the silks, so your body is in front of them.
steps.content: Lean forward through the silks, so your body is in front of them. Either extend your free leg in front of you, or bring it up to your knee in a passe. Try to make it look as pretty as possible.

steps.title: Begin with a single foot lock.
steps.content: Begin with a single foot lock. You can perform the half-moon from a climb or on the ground.

steps.title: Separate the silks.
steps.content: Separate the silks. Turn sideways and put your free foot directly in front of you so it pushes against one of the silks.

steps.title: Lean against the other silk and grip it above your head.
steps.content: Lean against the other silk and grip it above your head. Once you feel confident enough you can let go.

steps.title: Separate the silks.
steps.content: Separate the silks. Next swing your upper body through so that the silks make a V down your torso. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Squat down so your knees point outward.
steps.content: Squat down so your knees point outward. It's easier to do this move from a climb instead of from on the ground.

steps.title: Lean forward, and gravity will pull you upside down.
steps.content: Lean forward, and gravity will pull you upside down. This is a very relaxing move. Flipping upside down makes the Half-Buddha more dangerous than the others, so make sure you're ready and be careful.

steps.title: Separate the silks and put your free leg through them so that it's in front of you.
steps.content: Separate the silks and put your free leg through them so that it's in front of you. It's easiest to transition to the back walk-over from a climb. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Slide your hands down around your hips.
steps.content: Slide your hands down around your hips. Lean backwards and split as much as you can. The lower you place your hands, the further upside-down you will go.

steps.title: Practice caution when performing the Pegasus.
steps.content: Practice caution when performing the Pegasus. The move is the most dangerous because you go upside-down, but you must also be careful and not fall on your head.
